Description: Rim and upper body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior glazed black (very worn); exterior: thinly glazed black (or burning?) on rim; at top of wall reserved band, glazed below; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer Identifies the sherd as possibly belonging to a Type 9A or Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 9A and Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18) and Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. There is evidence of burning on the exterior surface of the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXII, no. 153)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 654, no. 114)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 50, no. 158)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.403) (Phase 3)
